NewWords.WordPhrase: n. readiness to cause pain or suffering to others; cruel actions 残忍；残酷
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He saw a lot of cruelty in the prison camp.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. likely to deceive; misleading 靠不住的；容易使人上当的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The newspapers promised not to run deceptive ads in the future.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. （同属人类的）人；同胞

NewWords.Word: for sb.'s (own) part/ the part of
NewWords.WordPhrase: as far as sb. is concerned至于…；对…来说
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Some young students, for their part, can stay up late playing computer games.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a person involved in trade or commerce 商人
a. clear; that can't be doubted 明确的，确切的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I was wandering round the shop with no very definite aim.

NewWords.WordPhrase: the same in all parts; the same as sth. else 浑然一体的；一致的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The style of the book is all of a piece, in both illustrations and text.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. tighten the skin of the face into lines or folds 使起皱纹
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The woman was forty, but looked fifty. Her cheeks were sunken and her skin was wrinkled and yellow.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  一致；符合  in accordance with in agreement or harmony with 与…一致；按照，依据
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Students will be criticized or punished if their behavior is not in accordance with school regulations.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. (of people) rather old; past middle age 较老的；上了年纪的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Traveling at 97 km/h (60 mph), an elderly driver may miss the information he or she needs or may act on the wrong information.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. obviously; it appears that 明显地，显然
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Evidently our living conditions are much better than before.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. showing love or tender feelings for (sb.) 充满爱的，亲切的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She gave me a very long and affectionate hug.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  (of people or their manner) gentle and kind; not severe or harsh 温和的； 不严厉的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Peter is a mild man, never getting angry easily.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. an alcoholic drink consisting of a spirit, or several spirits, mixed with fruit juice, etc. 鸡尾酒
a. exciting, esp. because of being slightly indecent; containing or tasting like spice 有刺激性的，粗俗的，有点下流的；（食品）用香料调味的，辛辣的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. You can often read spicy stories about film stars in the local newspapers.

NewWords.WordPhrase: to some degree 在某种程度上，有点儿
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. It's something of a disadvantage nowadays if you can't use a computer.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a tendency that one is born with to behave in a certain way without reasoning or training 本能，直觉
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. It is the mother's instinct to protect her children.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a public room in a hotel, club, etc. for waiting or relaxing in （旅馆等处的）休息室，休息厅
v. strike (the inner surface of one's hands) together 拍（手），击
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The noise of conversation rose, and the teacher clapped her hands for silence.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. (infml) a drink, esp. champagne, that has a lot of bubbles of gas 起泡和发嘶嘶声的饮料（如香槟酒等）
n. 汇款
ad.  in a strange manner 奇特地，古怪地   oddly enough (used to say that sth. seems strange or surprising) 说来奇怪
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Children's books, oddly enough, continued to have a big place in retail sales.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  a person or thing having the same name as another同姓、同名或同姓名的人；同名物
a. not easily explained; extraordinary 不可思议的；超常的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I had an uncanny feeling of being watched.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. drink (sth.), taking a very small amount each time 小口地喝，抿
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Jessica sipped her coffee, listening to the music.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. (infml)(BrE) a man or boy 家伙，小伙子
to a certain extent but not entirely 在某种程度上；从某一点上看
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I agree with you in a way, but there are still some areas on which I can't see eye to eye with you.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. 卷曲的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The girl with curly hair is waiting for her friend.

NewWords.WordPhrase: unwillingly and rudely/willingly and happily 勉强地/欣然地
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. After I talked to him for an hour, he admitted his mistake with a bad grace.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt.  pass the hand gently over (a surface), usu. several times 轻抚，抚摩，捋
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. At the sight of her husband getting off the train, the woman walked forward and embraced him and stroked his white hair.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. (shaved, shaved or shaven) cut (hair) off one's face, etc. with a razor; cut or scrape thin slices from the surface of （用剃刀）刮（胡须等）；刨，削
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He washed and shaved, then hurried out of the house.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 静脉；血管
a. allowing light to pass through so that objects behind can be seen clearly 透明的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Transparent plastic is often used for packaging foods, enabling the consumer to see the product inside.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. (infml) having no money; bankrupt 一文不名的，破了产的   go broke have no money; go bankrupt 一文不名，破产
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Many multinational companies went broke during the financial crisis, not to speak of small businesses.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. (fml) until now; until a particular time 迄今，到目前为止
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The Hope Project sent money to students hitherto unable to afford their tuition fees.

NewWords.WordPhrase: refuse to abandon or change (sth.) 坚持
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The old man stuck to jogging every morning although he was eighty years old.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt.  defeat; make (sth.) neat or smooth by cutting away irregular parts 击败；整修，修剪
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. They were trimmed by 3 goals to 2.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt.  典当，抵押
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He pawned his gold watch to pay the rent.

NewWords.WordPhrase: having no money, home, etc. 穷困潦倒
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. When he was down and out, none of his friends gave him a helping hand.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. do (sth. illegal or wrong) 犯（错误、罪行），干（坏事）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. It is illegal to commit violations of the copyright.

NewWords.WordPhrase: (of a person) have a breakdown; lose control of oneself 身体（或精神）垮下来；失去自制能力
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I was attracted by the story of a housewife who went to pieces as one disaster followed another.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. (infml) very foolish 蠢极的；荒唐的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. You would be insane to refuse the invitation to attend the conference.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a dim perception or faint idea 模糊的感觉（或认识）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We begin to see the glimmerings of a solution to the problem.

NewWords.WordPhrase: be trying to say 意指，要说
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The teacher didn't mention the word "cheating" but I knew what he was driving at.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  a light fixed on rocks or on the coast to warn or guide ships 灯塔；浮标
n. a narrow stretch of water flowing inland from a coast; a stream 小湾，小港；溪
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. tidal creeks teeming with shore wildlife

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. （水、空气等的）流，潮流  a. of the present time; happening now 现时的，当前的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Under normal conditions, the ocean currents of the tropical Pacific travel from east to west.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. by surprise 猝不及防地   be taken aback be shocked or surprised 吃一惊
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She was taken aback when a man answered the phone.

NewWords.WordPhrase: in bad/good health 身体状况不好/好
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He is in good condition again after a long holiday.

NewWords.WordPhrase: arrive; make one's appearance 来到；出现
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He didn't turn up until the end of the examination.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. (infml) avoid because of fear（因恐惧）避开
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. They were given a chance of taking part in the speech contest, but funked it.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. condition of a person's body with regard to health, strength, etc. 体格，体质；素质
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Having been ill for several years, he has a particularly fragile constitution.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  living a life of harmful pleasures and waste 放荡；玩乐
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Years of dissipation had ruined his health.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a thing, a matter or an activity that has little value or importance 小事；琐事   a trifle slightly 有点儿；稍微
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. George was a trifle awkward with girls but fond of dancing.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  not hiding one's thoughts; frank and honest 真诚坦率的；直言不讳的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Let me be absolutely candid with you: your work is not good enough.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. move one's hand, an object, etc. backwards and forwards repeatedly on a surface while pressing 摩擦；柔擦
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Coat the shoes with polish, then rub hard with a soft cloth to give a shine.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. unfilled position or post 空缺
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The company has a vacancy in the accounts department.
